nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: On the Way to the Park
nodes.text:
The walk to the park is familiar — cracks in the pavement, the smell of leaves, the rhythm of your child’s steps beside you. But today, something is different.

Your new partner will join you for the first time. Your child knows that ‘a friend’ might come, but the meaning of that word is still floating unspoken between you. Your child’s steps feel half a beat slower today—their way of scanning the emotional weather ahead.

choices.label: Name what’s happening in a simple, honest way.
choices.text: You say: “Hey, my friend Alex is joining us today. We’ve been spending some time together and I’d like you to meet.”

choices.label: Keep it vague and avoid defining the relationship.
choices.text: You say: “A friend might show up later,” then quickly change the subject, hoping not to stir worry.

choices.label: Overload the child with details about the relationship.
choices.text: You launch into how you met Alex, what you’ve talked about, and why nothing will change at home. Your child looks overwhelmed.

nodes.speaker: New Partner
nodes.title: First Hello
nodes.text:
At the park entrance, Alex spots you and waves. Your child subtly shifts behind you — not hiding, but watching, taking everything in.

Alex approaches with kind eyes and an uncertain smile. Alex’s uncertainty mirrors your own; first impressions carry the weight of every future possibility.

choices.label: Model a warm but low-pressure introduction.
choices.text: You say: “Alex, this is Maya. Maya, this is Alex. You don’t have to talk yet if you don’t feel like it.”

choices.label: Prompt the child to be extra friendly.
choices.text: You gently push: “Come on, say hi properly, don’t be rude.” The child stiffens.

choices.label: Let your partner take the lead completely.
choices.text: You stay quiet as Alex kneels and begins chatting directly to your child without any warm-up from you.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Shared Activity
nodes.text: The three of you drift toward the swings. Your child studies Alex in tiny glances — the kind that reveal everything. They’re deciding if this new person is safe, kind, and aware of their world. Tiny glances reveal more than words—the child is deciding whether this new person understands their world.

choices.label: Invite a simple joint activity the child can opt into.
choices.text: You ask gently: “Do you want us to push you together, or should I push and Alex watch?”

choices.label: Step aside and let your partner bond quickly and intensely.
choices.text: You tell Alex to go ahead and push while you scroll your phone. Your child’s eyes widen — too much, too fast.

choices.label: Keep your partner at a distance to ‘protect’ the child.
choices.text: You hover close, speaking only with your child, barely acknowledging Alex’s presence.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of the Outing
nodes.text:
On the walk home, your child holds your hand tightly. They’re quieter than usual — not upset, just sorting the day into pieces.

New people mean new shapes in their emotional world. Even small introductions have weight. Children sort new people like puzzle pieces, checking if the edges fit without losing the picture they already have.

choices.label: Invite a light, open check-in with the child.
choices.text: You ask: “How was it for you meeting Alex today? Anything you liked or didn’t like?”

choices.label: Avoid the topic to ‘keep things calm’.
choices.text: You talk about homework, dinner, and tomorrow’s plans — leaving their feelings unspoken.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Quick Reflection
nodes.text:
Introductions are never just about the new person — they’re about the child’s pace, the family’s history, and the invisible tug of feeling safe.

You take a breath, noticing today with clearer eyes. Introductions write early lines in a long story; pacing, choice, and clarity are the ink.

choices.label: Notice what you did to protect the child’s pace.
choices.text: You replay small moments where you offered choice, space, or clarity — the foundation of trust.

choices.label: Notice what you’d handle differently next time.
choices.text: You identify one shift — a phrasing, a pause, a tone — that will make the next introduction smoother.

acts.title: First Time Meeting the New Partner
